heading: 3.1 Functional enrichment analysis
text: Functional enrichment analysis (FEA) refers set computational approaches designed derive biological meaning lists biomolecules, genes, proteins, metabolites.focusing biological significance biomolecular changes, functional enrichment analysis enables researchers make sense complex high-throughput data large-scale studies, revealing key cellular processes signaling pathways involved health disease states.

heading: 3.1.1 Why Is It Important?
text: Large-scale omics studies often yield vast datasets hundreds thousands significantly regulated biomolecules. Manually investigating feature, individual genes proteins, can overwhelming inefficient.Functional enrichment analysis provides solution organising biomolecules meaningful categories, allowing identification overarching biological patterns mechanisms. helps reduce data complexity uncovers higher-level biological insights, discovering critical pathways involved disease progression identifying potential therapeutic targets. Thus, enrichment analysis crucial step interpretation high-dimensional omics data, transforming lists molecular entities actionable biological knowledge.

heading: 3.1.2 When to Use Functional Enrichment Analysis?
text: Functional enrichment analysis typically applied conducting differential expression analysis comparative analyses omics studies. step essential attempting derive biological insights large lists biomolecules exhibit significant changes expression, modification, abundance experimental groups. common scenarios functional enrichment analysis particularly valuable:Transcriptomics (eg high-fat diet vs. low-fat diet)Proteomics (eg tumor tissue vs. healthy tissue)Metabolomics (eg diabetic vs. non-diabetic patients)Lipidomics (eg disease vs. healthy state)Epigenomics (eg smokers vs. non-smokers)…

heading: 3.1.3 What Are the Input Data?
text: Functional enrichment analysis relies carefully prepared input data derived -omics study. data inputs typically consist various components depending type enrichment analysis. list features, ranked list, background set, gene sets pathway topology.

heading: 3.1.4 Synonyms
text: ’s important note term “functional enrichment analysis” often used different ways across field. diversity terminology can sometimes cause confusion, concept referred various synonymous terms. include:Enrichment analysisPathway analysisPathway enrichment analysisFunctional annotation analysisAnnotation enrichment analysisFunctional pathway analysisFunctional enrichment analysis…

gene list collection genes (proteins) particular interest biological experiment. list typically arises high-throughput experiments transcriptomics, proteomics, genomics, genes differentially expressed, mutated, otherwise identified significant. functional enrichment analysis, gene list used assess whether certain biological pathways, gene ontologies, functions statistically overrepresented compared reference background set.Gene List:
gene list collection genes (proteins) particular interest biological experiment. list typically arises high-throughput experiments transcriptomics, proteomics, genomics, genes differentially expressed, mutated, otherwise identified significant. functional enrichment analysis, gene list used assess whether certain biological pathways, gene ontologies, functions statistically overrepresented compared reference background set.Background Set:
background set, also referred “reference set,” complete set genes proteins gene list compared. background typically includes genes analysed experiment (e.g., genes microarray RNA-seq dataset). choice background crucial influences statistical significance enrichment. instance, using background includes expressed genes result different outcome compared using known genes genome.Background Set:
background set, also referred “reference set,” complete set genes proteins gene list compared. background typically includes genes analysed experiment (e.g., genes microarray RNA-seq dataset). choice background crucial influences statistical significance enrichment. instance, using background includes expressed genes result different outcome compared using known genes genome.P-value:
p-value measure probability observed result occurred chance. feature level, indicates whether particular gene protein shows significant differences (e.g., expression mutation) compared control baseline. example, p-value 0.01 gene means ’s 1% chance observed change gene due random variation. enrichment level, p-value evaluates whether overlap identified genes particular biological term (pathway) occurred chance. pathway p-value 0.001, instance, suggests ’s 0.1% probability pathway’s association gene list occurred randomly.P-value:
p-value measure probability observed result occurred chance. feature level, indicates whether particular gene protein shows significant differences (e.g., expression mutation) compared control baseline. example, p-value 0.01 gene means ’s 1% chance observed change gene due random variation. enrichment level, p-value evaluates whether overlap identified genes particular biological term (pathway) occurred chance. pathway p-value 0.001, instance, suggests ’s 0.1% probability pathway’s association gene list occurred randomly.False Discovery Rate (FDR):
FDR corrects multiple comparisons, many tests conducted feature enrichment levels. analysing thousands genes numerous pathways, likelihood false positives increases, FDR adjusts controlling proportion false positives among significant results. example, FDR threshold 0.05 means 5% features (e.g., genes) enriched terms (e.g., pathways) identified significant expected false positives.False Discovery Rate (FDR):
FDR corrects multiple comparisons, many tests conducted feature enrichment levels. analysing thousands genes numerous pathways, likelihood false positives increases, FDR adjusts controlling proportion false positives among significant results. example, FDR threshold 0.05 means 5% features (e.g., genes) enriched terms (e.g., pathways) identified significant expected false positives.Regulation:
context enrichment analysis, regulation refers upregulation downregulation genes. heading: 3.3 Types of Enrichment Analysis
text:
Khatri et al. (2012) nicely explained different types enrichment analysis, shown .
Figure 3.1: Types functional enrichment analysis
Source: Figure adapted Khatri P, Sirota M, Butte AJ. Ten years pathway analysis: current approaches outstanding challenges. PLoS Comput Biol. 2012;8(2):e1002375.

heading: 3.3.1 Over Representation Analysis (ORA)
text: Representation Analysis (ORA) one simplest widely used methods functional enrichment analysis. ORA aims determine whether specific biological categories (e.g., pathways, Gene Ontology terms) statistically overrepresented given list features (like genes proteins) compared background reference set. method focuses counting number features list associated specific category comparing count expected chance.

heading: 3.3.1.1 Input Data
text: List Features: refers subset biomolecules identified significantly regulated altered study. Features might include genes, proteins, lipids, biomolecules, depending type -omics data.List Features: refers subset biomolecules identified significantly regulated altered study. Features might include genes, proteins, lipids, biomolecules, depending type -omics data.Background Set: background set, universe, consists features measured study defined subset total genome, proteome, metabolome studied. background critical enrichment analysis provides context significance feature enrichment assessed.Background Set: background set, universe, consists features measured study defined subset total genome, proteome, metabolome studied. background critical enrichment analysis provides context significance feature enrichment assessed.

heading: 3.3.1.2 Workflow
text: works: ORA uses predefined feature list (e.g., differentially expressed genes), calculates number features list belong certain category (e.g., pathway), tests whether number significantly higher expected using statistical tests like hypergeometric test Fisher’s exact test.Strengths: Simple easy implement. Works well predefined list significant features.Limitations: ORA take account full range feature expression values can miss subtle changes across broader set features. relies heavily selecting predefined cut-create feature list, can subjective.

heading: 3.3.2 Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA)
text: Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) also known Functional Class Scoring (FCS) sophisticated method avoids need define strict cut-selecting list significant features. Instead using discrete list differentially expressed features, GSEA analyses ranked feature expression data. evaluates whether predefined gene sets (pathways functional categories) enriched top bottom ranked list, capturing subtle coordinated changes gene expression.

heading: 3.3.2.1 Input Data
text: Ranked List: enrichment methods, Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA), ranked list used instead simple feature list. ranking typically based continuous metric magnitude gene expression changes sort statistical test output. ranked list helps prioritise features exhibit strongest biological relevance facilitates nuanced enrichment analyses consider direction strength biomolecular changes.Ranked List: enrichment methods, Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA), ranked list used instead simple feature list. ranking typically based continuous metric magnitude gene expression changes sort statistical test output. ranked list helps prioritise features exhibit strongest biological relevance facilitates nuanced enrichment analyses consider direction strength biomolecular changes.Gene Sets: refers predefined groups genes share common biological property, involvement specific biological pathway, functional category, regulatory process. commonly used format gene sets MSigDB GMT format. format simple, human-readable, widely supported various GSEA tools.Gene Sets: refers predefined groups genes share common biological property, involvement specific biological pathway, functional category, regulatory process. commonly used format gene sets MSigDB GMT format. format simple, human-readable, widely supported various GSEA tools.

heading: 3.3.2.2 Workflow
text: works: GSEA first ranks genes dataset according differential expression levels (e.g., control condition). , predefined gene set, calculates enrichment score (ES) reflects concentration gene set members extremes ranked list. Statistical significance assessed permutation testing, False Discovery Rate (FDR) used correct multiple comparisons.Strengths: GSEA avoids arbitrary thresholds feature selection can detect coordinated changes across sets genes, even individual genes within set show significant differential expression.Limitations: GSEA may miss smaller pathways functional categories features highly ranked uniformly expressed. also computationally intensive ORA.

heading: 3.3.3 Pathway Topology (PT)-Based Enrichment
text: Pathway Topology (PT)-based enrichment analysis extends beyond merely counting features instead incorporates topological structure biological pathways. method evaluates features part pathway also position interactions within pathway. considering connectivity interaction strength features, PT-based approaches provide biologically meaningful interpretation pathway activation suppression.

heading: 3.3.3.1 Input Data
text: List Features Ranked List: Already explained.Pathway Topology: refers structure biological pathway, includes detailed information interactions relationships gene products (proteins RNAs) within pathway.

heading: 3.3.3.2 Workflow
text:
works: PT-based methods take account direction magnitude feature expression changes, well structure pathways (e.g., signaling cascades, metabolic pathways). consider biomolecule products interact one another specific roles gene within pathway. Topological factors like number connections gene centrality pathway considered assessing enrichment.Strengths: Provides biologically relevant insights considering gene-gene interactions position gene within pathway. particularly useful complex pathways roles genes differ based interactions others.Limitations: Requires detailed pathway annotations higher computational complexity. Pathway databases may complete accurate topological information pathways, limiting analysis certain datasets.PT-based enrichment covered workshop:
Given focus workshop widely used accessible enrichment methods, PT-based analysis covered limited practical applications (primarily due insufficient availability comprehensive well-annotated pathway topology databases). Instead, focus methods like ORA GSEA, better supported existing databases easier apply typical omics studies. However, participants encouraged explore PT-based enrichment future database resources improve.

heading: 3.4 Annotation Databses
text: Functional annotation databases curated collections biological data systematically categorise describe functions, roles, interactions, pathways genes, proteins, biological molecules, enabling researchers link experimental data biological knowledge.

heading: 3.4.1 GO: Gene Ontology
text:
“goal Gene Ontology Consortium produce dynamic, controlled vocabulary can applied eukaryotes even knowledge gene protein roles cells accumulating changing.” (Ashburner et al. 2000)
Figure 3.2: structure gene ontology.
Imagen source Gene Ontology HandbookGene Ontology (GO) structured framework used describe roles genes products across living organisms. provides controlled vocabulary allows consistent descriptions gene functions, biological processes, cellular locations, facilitating computational analysis integration biological data across different species. GO’s structure comprises three main aspects:1. Molecular Function:
Gene Ontology (GO), molecular function refers specific biochemical activity gene product (protein RNA) performs. activity typically involves direct physical interactions molecular entities, catalysis binding. functions described based biochemical roles (e.g., enzyme activity) contribution components within larger biological systems. instance, protein kinase activity involves phosphorylation proteins, specific molecular function. GO, molecular function concerned direct action gene products, whether terms biochemical interactions roles larger biological systems.2. Biological Process:
Biological processes represent larger objectives gene products contribute organism, often described outcome result series molecular events. processes broader, coordinated sequences molecular activities achieve biological objective, cell division DNA replication. biological process GO can encompass anything simple enzymatic actions complex, regulated systems like embryonic development immune response. GO annotations aim associate gene products processes directly contribute also processes regulate enable.3. Cellular Component:
aspect GO refers specific location within cell gene product operates. Cellular components described relative structures within cell, mitochondrion plasma membrane, reflect molecular functions occur part broader biological processes. locations vital understanding molecular activities take place, cellular compartmentalisation often influences function regulation gene products. Unlike molecular function biological process, cellular components refer cellular anatomy, specifying gene products perform roles biological activities.practice, GO terms annotations allow researchers describe gene functions standardised way, helping tasks gene function prediction, functional profiling, comparing genes across species. GO’s hierarchical organisation terms provides rich framework model complexity biological systems facilitates computational study gene functions.

heading: 3.4.2 KEGG: Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes
text:
Kyoto Encyclopedia Genes Genomes (KEGG) curated database integrates genomic, chemical, systemic information represent biological systems interactions. allows users map molecular data (genes, proteins, small molecules) biological pathways, enabling better understanding different components interact within organism.
Figure 3.3: NOTCH Signaling Pathway KEGG

heading: 3.4.3 Reactome
text:
Reactome pathway knowledgebase open-access, manually curated database captures molecular details biological processes signal transduction, DNA replication, metabolism, , using consistent data model across different domains biology. makes particularly well-suited functional enrichment analysis, understanding relationships gene expression data biological pathways crucial.
Figure 3.4: NOTCH Signaling Pathway Reactome

heading: 3.4.4 MSigDB
text:
Molecular Signatures Database (MSigDB) comprehensive resource gene set enrichment analysis. offers comprehensive collection gene sets represent biological processes, molecular pathways, biologically relevant information. MSigDB integrated Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) tool, commonly used determine predefined sets genes show statistically significant differences two biological states (e.g., diseased vs. healthy samples).
Figure 3.5: GSEA Workflow

heading: 4 Enrichment Statistics

Enrichment statistics based contingency table like :based 16,000 genes measured experiment.Note genes may measured; excluded entirely calculations.

heading: 4.1 Fisher’s Exact Test
text:
Fisher’s Exact Test statistical test used determine nonrandom associations proportions two categorical variables. calculates exact probability observing given distribution counts 2x2 contingency table, null hypothesis association variables.Note: just toy calculator training, quite limited. can also use online tools like Social Science Statistics play .Formula:
\[P = \frac{(+ b)!(c + d)!(+ c)!(b + d)!}{!b!c!d!N!}\]:\(\), \(b\), \(c\), \(d\) observed counts 2x2 contingency table.\(\), \(b\), \(c\), \(d\) observed counts 2x2 contingency table.\(N\) total number observations, \(N = + b + c + d\).\(N\) total number observations, \(N = + b + c + d\).Given contingency table:
code:
a = 30
b = 270
c = 470
d = 15230

data <- matrix(c(a, b, c, d), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)

# One-tailed test
fisher.test(data, alternative = "g") # greater or "less"

heading: 4.2 Hypergeometric Test
text:
Hypergeometric test calculates probability observing given number genes specific category (e.g., pathway) gene list (differentially expressed genes) chance. models situation draw sample (gene list) finite population (background genes), success defined gene category (e.g., belonging pathway).Note: tool Stat Trek play around hypergeometric test.Formula:
\[P(X = k) = \frac{\binom{K}{k} \binom{N - K}{n - k}}{\binom{N}{n}}\]
:\(k\) = Number success items sample (overlap).\(k\) = Number success items sample (overlap).\(n\) = Number items sample (DE genes).\(n\) = Number items sample (DE genes).\(K\) = Number success items population (term).\(K\) = Number success items population (term).\(N\) = Total number items population (background).\(N\) = Total number items population (background).parameters example:
k=30; n=300; K=500; N=16000;:k−1 number observed successes minus 1 (“least” scenario).
lower.tail = FALSE gives probability getting least k successes (right-tail).
code:
# Observed value
k <- a
n <- a + b
K <- a + c
N <- a + b + c + d

# (P[X >= k])
phyper(k - 1, K, N - K, n, lower.tail = FALSE)

heading: 4.4 Kolmogorov–Smirnov (KS)–like Test
text:
Kolmogorov–Smirnov (KS)–like test used Functional Class Scoring approaches Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) test whether genes predefined set non-randomly distributed near top bottom ranked list genes.test computes running-sum statistic walks ranked list:running sum increases gene set encountered (weighted strength rank statistic).running sum increases gene set encountered (weighted strength rank statistic).decreases gene set encountered.decreases gene set encountered.maximum deviation zero enrichment score (ES).maximum deviation zero enrichment score (ES).significance observed ES estimated permutation testing, generating null distribution calculate p-values, followed FDR correction multiple comparisons.According Subramanian et al. (2005), enrichment score defined :\[
P_{\text{hit}}(S,) = \sum_{\substack{g_j \S \\ j \le }} \frac{|r_j|^{p}}{N_R}
\]\[
P_{\text{miss}}(S,) = \sum_{\substack{g_j \notin S \\ j \le }} \frac{1}{N - N_H}
\]\[
\mathrm{ES}(S) = \max_i \big[ P_{\text{hit}}() - P_{\text{miss}}() \big]
\]Explanation Terms:(Adapted Subramanian et al., 2005, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.. 102:15545–15550.)

heading: 5.1 SH-SY5Y Differentiation
text:
SH-SY5Y commonly used neuroblastoma cell line.
appropriate treatment, can induced differentiate ‘neuronal’ form.
Differentiated cells look quite different, growing thin neurites body cell.
Figure 5.1: Morphological analysis differentiated SH-SY5Y cells.6-DIV stage, cells exposed RA showed elongated morphology compared basal medium (NT). Cells subsequently treated NBM 3 days became polarised, exhibited several neurites branches acquired neuronal-like shapeImage derived Figure 4 (Pezzini et al. 2017).

heading: 5.2 The question: What pathways are involved in SH-SY5Y Differentiation?
text: paper Transcriptomic Profiling Discloses Molecular Cellular Events Related Neuronal Differentiation SH-SY5Y Neuroblastoma Cells, Pezzini et al. induced neuronal differentiation SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cell line measured transcriptomic changes using RNA sequencing (Pezzini et al. 2017). 9-day differentiation protocol, SH-SY5Y cells initially pre-differentiated retinoic acid (RA) medium 6 days, followed 3-day treatment neurobasal medium (NBM) enriched neurotrophic factors. Control cells, treated (NT), maintained basal conditions served comparison group. authors performed functional enrichment analysis differentially expressed genes.

heading: 7 Online Tools
text: Functional enrichment analysis can performed using various web-based tools, designed meet specific analytical needs. tools often vary databases use, statistical approaches, capabilities perform different types analysis, -Representation Analysis (ORA) Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA).workshop, explore several popular tools functional enrichment analysis, including gProfiler, STRING, Reactome, MSigDB GSEA. tool offers unique features insights, providing flexibility selecting right method diverse datasets research questions.
gProfiler known integration numerous species databases. supports ORA GSEA, enabling users assess Gene Ontology (GO), biological pathways, regulatory motifs protein databases. gProfile one can

heading: 7.1.1 Steps to perform ORA in g:Profiler:
text:
- Prepare Input List: Ensure input formatted one gene per line suitable format g:Profiler.- Input Gene List: Paste prepared gene list directly input box g:Profiler web page upload file containing list.- Select Organism: Choose appropriate organism Organism dropdown menu (e.g., Homo sapiens human data).- Choose Statistical Domain Scope: Advanced options, select preferred statistical background Statistical domain scope menu.choose “Custom” background, provide custom background list pasting uploading relevant file.- Set Significance Threshold: Select desired significance threshold method, g:SCS, Bonferroni, Benjamini-Hochberg.
- Specify threshold value (e.g., 0.05, 0.1, etc.).- Select Functional Annotation Databases:  Navigate Data sources tab choose one databases analysis. Available options include:Gene Ontology (GO): Biological Process, Molecular Function, Cellular Component.KEGG PathwaysReactome PathwaysWikiPathwaysTRANSFACmirTarBaseHuman Protein AtlasCORUMHuman Phenotype Ontology (HP)- Run Query: Run analysis review enriched terms, pathways, visual outputs. Download results needed exploration.

STRING (Search Tool Retrieval Interacting Genes/Proteins) resource exploring protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks. combines experimental data, predictions, curated information build networks highlight functional relationships, helping reveal shared pathways biological processes within gene protein lists.

heading: 7.2.1 Steps to Perform ORA in STRING:
text: - Select Multiple proteins tab.- Input Gene List: Paste prepared gene list directly input box STRING web page upload file containing list.- Select Organism: Choose appropriate organism Organisms dropdown menu (e.g., Homo sapiens human data). STRING auto-detect organism ENSEMBL IDs provided.- Modify Settings: Advanced Settings, can modify Required score low (0.15) highest (0.9) confidence. Similarly FDR stringency Network type can selected.NOTE: cases long list features provided, STRING may chnage settings :nodes simplified (3D) designpreviews protein structures shownthe network edges show interaction confidence

text:
One essential tabs Analysis tab, offers comprehensive functional enrichment analysis range databases. include Gene Ontology (GO) biological processes, molecular functions, cellular components; Pathway enrichment sources KEGG, Reactome, WikiPathways; significant data sources Human Phenotype annotations UniProt protein function structure.Columns STRING enrichment table explained following:- Count Network:
first number indicates many proteins network annotated particular term. second number indicates many proteins total (network background) term assigned. can click numbers see network view gene sets behind .- Strength:
Log10(observed / expected). measure describes large enrichment effect . ’s ratio ) number proteins network annotated term ii) number proteins expect annotated term random network size.- Signal:
signal defined weighted harmonic mean observed/expected ratio -log(FDR). FDR tends emphasise larger terms due potential achieving lower p-values, observed/expected ratio highlights smaller terms, high foreground background ratio achieve low FDR values due size. signal measure seeks balance metrics intuittive ordering enriched terms.- False Discovery Rate:
measure describes significant enrichment . Shown p-values corrected multiple testing within category using Benjamini–Hochberg procedure.STRING visualises terms within category using bubble plot, effectively showcasing significance size enriched terms. Additionally, renders groups related terms based user-defined similarity level, allowing users identify clusters functionally related terms within data. helps interpreting complex enrichment results highlighting key biological processes pathways closely associated.

Figure 7.4: Statistical background

text:
Clusters tab essentially provides three different types clustering algorithms:k-means clustering: Initialise k centroids randomly, assigns data point nearest centroid, recompute centroids mean points cluster centroids change significantly.k-means clustering: Initialise k centroids randomly, assigns data point nearest centroid, recompute centroids mean points cluster centroids change significantly.MCL clustering (Markov clustering): graph-based algorithm uses flow simulation detect clusters network modeling random walks.MCL clustering (Markov clustering): graph-based algorithm uses flow simulation detect clusters network modeling random walks.DBSCAN clustering: density-based algorithm groups points closely packed together marking points low-density regions outliers noiseDBSCAN clustering: density-based algorithm groups points closely packed together marking points low-density regions outliers noise

Among supported tools Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA), implements MSigDB GSEA analysis identifying enriched gene sets genomic data.MSigDB (Molecular Signatures Database) collection gene sets Gene Set Enrichment Analysis, representing pathways gene signatures linked biological states diseases. helps identify enriched gene sets, aiding analysis gene expression changes key pathways experimental data.

heading: 7.3.2 Steps to Perform GSEA:
text: Basic Parameters- Create .gct .cls files following scrit R- Load .gct input file expression dataset tab .cls file phenotype labels tab- Select .gmt file (Gene Matrix Transposed) gene sets database tab- Set permutation number permutations tab- Type permuattaion set permutation type tab- Select appropriate DNA Chip annotation file chip platform file tab- Name output file output file name tabAdvanced Parameters- Scoring Scheme:K-S: score increment genes S regardless ranking correlation strength.K-S: score increment genes S regardless ranking correlation strength.WEighted: score increment gene S weighted correlation phenotype, typically absolute value correlation ranking metric.WEighted: score increment gene S weighted correlation phenotype, typically absolute value correlation ranking metric.- Metric ranking genes: Ranking metric interest can chosen drop menu. detailed description od metrics given GSEA-MSigDB Documentation.Categorical Phenotypes: Signal--Noise Ratio, t-Test, Ratio Classes, Log2 Ratio ClassesCategorical Phenotypes: Signal--Noise Ratio, t-Test, Ratio Classes, Log2 Ratio ClassesContinuous Phenotypes: Pearson Correlation, Spearman CorrelationContinuous Phenotypes: Pearson Correlation, Spearman Correlation- Minimum Maximum size gene sets can set using max gene set size min gene set size tabs

heading: 7.5 Uncertainties of a functional enrichment analsysis
text:
section provides summary paper Wünsch et al. (2023), explores uncertainties inherent functional enrichment analysis. study critically examines sources variability challenges analytical approach, offering insights improving reliability robustness.
Figure 7.21: RNA sequencing measurements final results: practical guide navigating choices uncertainties gene set analysis

heading: 7.5.1 Types of FEA
text: Functional enrichment analysis (FEA) typically involves one representation analysis (ORA), gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) also known functional class scoring (FCS), Pathway Topology (PT).ORA- ORA methods least complex among three approaches FEA.- ORA methods requires list differentially expressed genes already analysed differential expression analysis.- background population, universe, can general set gene like human genome specific thos observed experiment.- contingency table created null distribution modeled using hypergeometric distribution.FCS- FCS methods aim aggregate values gene-level statistics (ranks) gene set-level statistic (enrichment score, ES).- FCS can classified one FCS , take expression data input FCS II take pre-ranked list genes input. latter, information conditions (phenotypes) samples lost, phenotype permutation performed leaving choice null hypothesis gene set permutation.PT- PT additionally models interactions genes. approach generally scores considerably lower terms popularity reference database.

heading: 7.5.2 Considerations
text: - Pre-filter expression data: Exclude lowly expressed genes improve statistical power.- Handle gene IDs carefully: Convert gene IDs required format remove duplicates.- Normalise expression data: Address sample-specific biases enable fair comparisons samples.- Use appropriate methods differential expression analysis: Recommended methods include limma (voom), DESeq2, edgeR.- Select suitable gene-level statistics: FCS II, choose metrics like moderated t-statistic rank genes meaningfully.- Adjust multiple testing: Ensure analysis includes correction multiple hypothesis testing. methods require manual adjustments.- Choose gene set databases based biological context: Ensure database aligns research question experimental system.

heading: 7.5.3 Recommendation
text:
Awareness Uncertainties:
- Recognise uncertainties methods, parameter choices, data preprocessing conducting Gene Set Analysis (GSA).
- Understand method’s name alone capture full analysis pipeline.Awareness Uncertainties:- Recognise uncertainties methods, parameter choices, data preprocessing conducting Gene Set Analysis (GSA).- Understand method’s name alone capture full analysis pipeline.Clearly document analysis choices, including methods, parameters, preprocessing steps.Clearly document analysis choices, including methods, parameters, preprocessing steps.Select methods, parameters, preprocessing steps starting analysis minimise bias.Select methods, parameters, preprocessing steps starting analysis minimise bias.Set Technical Parameters:
- Fix technical parameters like random seed number permutations running analysis ensure reproducibility.
- Avoid adjusting parameters obtain favorable results.Set Technical Parameters:- Fix technical parameters like random seed number permutations running analysis ensure reproducibility.- Avoid adjusting parameters obtain favorable results.Avoid Cherry-picking:
- Refrain selectively reporting results based favorable outcomes, can lead -optimistic non-reproducible findings.
- Avoid excessive tweaking analysis strategy fit data post hoc.Avoid Cherry-picking:- Refrain selectively reporting results based favorable outcomes, can lead -optimistic non-reproducible findings.- Avoid excessive tweaking analysis strategy fit data post hoc.Use different pipelines parameter configurations part sensitivity analysis check consistency results.Use different pipelines parameter configurations part sensitivity analysis check consistency results.Share complete analysis workflows, including code documentation, allow others replicate findings accurately.Share complete analysis workflows, including code documentation, allow others replicate findings accurately.

heading: 9 Resources
text: following tools might useful downstream functional analysis; includes covered todays workshop.Note tools just enrichment tests, include databases.

heading: 9.1 g:Profiler / g:GOSt
text:
https://biit.cs.ut.ee/gprofiler/gostThe g:GOSt ‘functional profiling’ tool gProfilercalculates functional enrichment gene lists, identifying enriched terms across various ontologies pathways.
features clean, modern interface provides handy summary highlighting genes contribute enrichment.
Figure 9.1: gProfiler front page

heading: 9.2 PANTHER
text:
http://www.pantherdb.org/PANTHER performs overrepresentation tests across multiple databases; Gene ontology, reactome, PANTHER pathways protein classes. Allows control statistical test used clearly summarises actually done.
Figure 9.2: PANTHER

heading: 9.3 DAVID
text:
https://david.ncifcrf.gov/Via ‘functional annotation’ tool, DAVID allows calculate functional enrichment across number databases ; Gene Ontology, KEGG, reactome others. Reliable, slightly clunky interface.
Figure 9.3: DAVID

heading: 9.4 Enrichr
text:
https://amp.pharm.mssm.edu/Enrichr/Enrichr easily calculates enrichment across wide range databases. Currently allow background set.

https://reactome.org/core reactome reactome pathways browser. ALthough tools use reactome database, reactome website provides means browse enrichment within pathway browser view.

text:
https://biocyc.org/Biocyc another suite tools enrichment pathway browsing, particularly useful prokaryotic work. licensed, Monash license.

text:
https://string-db.org/STRING originally designed convenient tool explore interactions within gene list, visualised interaction network. best suited smaller gene lists, now also includes functionality performing functional enrichment analysis.

http://geneontology.org/Gene Ontology (GO) terms widely use set functional annotations, used many enrichment tools. gene ontology resource website provides several tools browsing GO term hierarchy.

heading: 9.9 KEGG
text:
https://www.genome.jp/kegg/well known curated pathway database. used many tools caveat - KEGG moved subscription model 2011, enrichment tools need use last open release 2011. However date KEGG pathways browsable directly website.

heading: 9.10 GSEA and MSigDB
text:
http://software.broadinstitute.org/gsea/index.jspThe GSEA Desktop (one many) gene set enrichment approaches. uses gene rankings across genes rather hypogeometric fishers-exact tests gene list enrichment. MSigDB (Molecular signatures database) suite annotation databases suitable GSEA analysis.

text:
MetaboAnalyst popular among metabolomics community statistical, functional integrative analysis metabolomics data. feature called Functional enrichment analysis, performs metabolite set enrichment analysis, metabolic pathway analysis, pathway activity prediction MS peaks.
